calm.title: Calm
calm.description: Lower heart rate and blood pressure

focus.title: Focus
focus.description: More oxygen to brain for clearer thinking

session.title: Breathing Session
session.subtitle: 4:6 Calming Rhythm
session.sessionProgressAriaLabel: Session progress: {current} of {total} breathing cycles completed

completion.title: Excellent Work
completion.description: You've completed {count} breathing cycles in {time}. Your parasympathetic nervous system has been activated, promoting relaxation.

whatHappens.title: What happens in your body
whatHappens.description: Controlled breathing through the 4:6 pattern which emphasizes a longer exhalation stimulates the vagus nerve, a primary component of the parasympathetic nervous system. Activating this nerve sends signals that help transition the body from a "fight or flight" state to a "rest and repair" mode.
whatHappens.benefits: This shift has several measurable physiological benefits. It can lead to a lower heart rate and reduced blood pressure. The relaxation of blood vessels allows for improved circulation, increasing oxygen flow to the brain. Furthermore, this calming response positively influences digestion and supports the body's immune system.
whatHappens.practice: Consciously practicing 4:6 breathing technique is an effective way to manage stress and promote overall well-being.

inhale.title: 4-Second Inhale
inhale.description: Steady breathing in brings fresh oxygen to your brain and helps you focus.

exhale.title: 6-Second Exhale
exhale.description: The longer out-breath signals your body to slow down and relax.

science.title: The Science Behind Breathing
science.description: Research shows that diaphragmatic breathing lowers cortisol levels and heart rate variability, with studies finding it reduces stress markers by up to 20% in healthy adults. A clinical trial on postoperative patients reported a 15% drop in anxiety scores after using the 4-7-8 method.

cortisol.title: Stress Hormone Reduction
cortisol.description: Controlled breathing techniques significantly lower cortisol levels. One review found that deep breathing practices reduce stress markers by up to 20% in healthy adults, with effects visible within a single session.

anxiety.title: Clinical Anxiety Relief
anxiety.description: Meta-analyses confirm that breathwork cuts mental health symptoms, including anxiety, by an average effect size of 0.32 across 12 randomized trials. Researchers observed that practices emphasizing extended exhales, like cyclic sighing, yield a 25% greater mood improvement than mindfulness alone.

vagal.title: Vagal Tone Enhancement
vagal.description: An experiment with older adults noted improved vagal tone and a 10% decrease in state anxiety following a single session of deep, slow breathing. In clinical settings, deep breathing has decreased physiological arousal in stress-prone groups, with effects lasting up to 12 weeks of regular use.

whenToPractice.title: When to practice
items: When you feel overwhelmed or stressed
Before important conversations or decisions
During anxiety or panic episodes
After stressful events to reset your nervous system

whatYoullNotice.title: What you'll notice
items: Immediate calming effect within the first minute
Clearer thinking and improved decision-making
Slower heart rate and reduced muscle tension
Better stress resilience with regular practice

posture.title: Posture
posture.description: Sit or stand straight to allow full lung expansion. Shoulders relaxed, not hunched.

environment.title: Environment
environment.description: Find a quiet space where you won't be interrupted. Comfortable temperature helps focus.

consistency.title: Consistency
consistency.description: Practice the same technique for a week before switching. Building familiarity improves effectiveness.

exercise.title: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding
exercise.groundedDescription: By engaging your five senses, you've successfully anchored yourself in the present moment.

immediateStability.title: Immediate Stability

calmPresence.title: Calm Presence
calmPresence.description: Feel more present and in control

items.text: Something with a interesting color or pattern
items.guidance: Look for textures, reflections, or color combinations that catch your eye
Notice how light hits the surface - is it glossy, matte, or somewhere in between?

items.text: Something that's moving or has shadows
items.guidance: Watch how movement creates changing patterns of light and shadow

items.text: A detail you hadn't noticed before
items.guidance: Look closer at familiar objects - what small details have you missed?
Focus on why this object feels comforting - its colors, shape, or memories it holds

touch.title: Feel around you
touch.subtitle: Find 4 things you can touch or feel

items.text: The temperature of the air on your skin
items.guidance: Notice if it's warm, cool, or neutral - how does it feel on different parts of your body?
Feel the fabric between your fingers - is it soft, rough, smooth, or textured?

items.text: The surface you're sitting or standing on
items.guidance: Press into it slightly - is it firm, soft, warm, or cool against your body?

items.text: Something smooth or rough near you
items.guidance: Run your fingers along the surface - notice the contrast in textures
Close your eyes and focus inward - can you hear your breath or pulse?
Listen beyond the room - what distant sounds can you identify?
Notice quiet sounds like humming electronics, air movement, or settling noises
Take a slow, deep breath - is it fresh, stale, scented, or neutral?
Look for subtle scents - coffee, soap, fabric softener, or natural smells

items.text: The current taste in your mouth
items.guidance: Run your tongue around your mouth - sweet, salty, minty, or just the taste of saliva?

neurological.title: Neurological Impact
neurological.description: The 5-4-3-2-1 technique redirects attention from internal anxious thoughts to external sensory experiences. This engages your prefrontal cortex while calming the amygdalaâ€”your brain's alarm system.
neurological.awareness: When you systematically use your five senses, it activates present-moment awareness and breaks the cycle of anxious thinking patterns.

stability.title: Immediate Stability
stability.description: The structured sequence (5 things to see, 4 to touch, etc.) gives your mind a concrete focus during chaotic mental states, preventing further spiraling into anxiety.
stability.grounding: This technique provides immediate grounding by connecting you with your physical environment and current reality.

science.title: The Science Behind Grounding
science.description: This sensory method appears in interventions for distress tolerance, where it interrupts rumination and lowers acute discomfort in teens with mood issues. In disaster recovery programs, participants practicing the technique showed a 12% reduction in post-traumatic stress symptoms over four sessions.

regulation.title: Self-Regulation Improvement
regulation.description: Studies on similar grounding tools report improved self-regulation, with one tool validation finding 85% inter-rater reliability in assessing reduced dissociation. Combined with emotion regulation training, it contributes to an 18% drop in impulse control problems among adolescents.

anxiety.title: Anxiety Reduction
anxiety.description: Nature-based versions enhance present-moment awareness, correlating with a 10-15% decrease in generalized anxiety in lifestyle medicine contexts. In disaster recovery programs, participants showed a 12% reduction in post-traumatic stress symptoms over four sessions.

stability.title: Emotional Stability
stability.description: For autistic individuals, grounding aids in managing overstimulation, as noted in self-compassion programs where users reported better emotional stability. Combined with emotion regulation training, it contributes to an 18% drop in impulse control problems among adolescents.

When racing thoughts won't stop
Feeling disconnected from reality
When situations feel overwhelming

timing.title: Timing
timing.description: Don't rush through the steps. Spend time really observing each sense.

detail.title: Detail
detail.description: Notice details like colors, textures, temperatures, and specific sounds.

practice.title: Practice
practice.description: Use this technique even when calm to build familiarity for anxious moments.

interface.excellentWork: Excellent work! You've completed {completedCycles} cycles of {techniqueName} in {totalTime}.

science.title: The Science Behind Guided Breathing
science.description: Guided sessions in virtual environments reduced treatment-related anxiety by 22% in patients facing invasive procedures. Device-guided breathing lowered test anxiety scores by an average of 14 points on the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory in students.

effectiveness.title: Enhanced Effectiveness
effectiveness.description: Randomized trials show guided methods outperform unguided ones, with a 0.45 effect size on mood enhancement when sessions exceed five minutes. A feasibility study on COPD patients found twice-daily guided practice cut dyspnea and anxiety by 20% over eight weeks.

clinical.title: Clinical Applications
clinical.description: In older adults, video-delivered relaxation breathing decreased symptom severity by 18% compared to psychoeducation alone. Device-guided breathing lowered test anxiety scores by an average of 14 points in pilot studies with students.

longterm.title: Long-term Benefits
longterm.description: Longer-term effects include a 15% improvement in quality of life for epilepsy patients after 20-minute mindful breathing sessions. A feasibility study on COPD patients found twice-daily guided practice cut dyspnea and anxiety by 20% over eight weeks.

boxBreathing.title: Box Breathing (4-4-4-4)
boxBreathing.description: Equal timing for all phases creates mental clarity and focus. Used by Navy SEALs and emergency responders to maintain calm under pressure. The symmetrical pattern helps regulate your nervous system and improve concentration.
boxBreathing.bestFor: Best for: Focus, concentration, stress management

calming.title: 4-7-8 Calming
calming.description: Extended hold allows oxygen to fully saturate your blood, while the long exhale activates your parasympathetic nervous system. This technique is particularly effective for reducing anxiety and preparing for sleep.
calming.bestFor: Best for: Anxiety relief, sleep preparation, deep relaxation

energizing.title: 4-4-6 Energizing
energizing.description: Balanced pattern that increases oxygen flow while maintaining control. The moderate exhale helps clear mental fog and boost alertness without causing hyperventilation.
energizing.bestFor: Best for: Mental clarity, energy boost, midday reset

quickReset.title: 3-3-3 Quick Reset
quickReset.description: Faster rhythm for immediate stress relief when you only have a minute or two. Perfect for moments of acute anxiety or when you need quick emotional regulation.
quickReset.bestFor: Best for: Quick stress relief, emergency calm, busy schedules

howItWorks.title: How guided breathing works
howItWorks.description1: Structured breathing patterns give your mind something specific to focus on, interrupting anxious thoughts. The timing cues help regulate your autonomic nervous system - the part that controls stress responses automatically.
howItWorks.description2: Each technique targets different aspects of relaxation. Longer exhales activate your body's "rest and digest" mode, while controlled holds optimize oxygen exchange and build mental resilience.

focusedAttention.title: Focused Attention
focusedAttention.description: Counting and timing keeps your mind occupied and present

nervousSystem.title: Nervous System
nervousSystem.description: Different patterns activate different relaxation responses

skillBuilding.title: Skill Building
skillBuilding.description: Regular practice improves your natural stress resilience

posture.title: Posture
posture.description: Sit or stand straight to allow full lung expansion. Shoulders relaxed, not hunched.

environment.title: Environment
environment.description: Find a quiet space where you won't be interrupted. Comfortable temperature helps focus.

consistency.title: Consistency
consistency.description: Practice the same technique for a week before switching. Building familiarity improves effectiveness.

completion.title: Deep Relaxation Achieved
completion.description: You've systematically released tension throughout your entire body. Notice how different your muscles feel compared to when you started.

howItWorks.title: What happens in your body
howItWorks.description: Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) works by teaching your body to recognize the difference between tension and relaxation. When you deliberately tense a muscle group for 5 seconds and then release it, you activate the relaxation response, which is the opposite of the stress response that contributes to anxiety and physical tension.
howItWorks.physiology: This technique leverages a natural physiological principle: after a muscle contracts intensely, it automatically relaxes more deeply than it would at rest. This rebound effect helps achieve a state of relaxation that's deeper than what you can typically reach through willpower alone. The systematic progression through different muscle groups ensures your entire body benefits from this relaxation response.
howItWorks.awareness: PMR also helps break the cycle of chronic muscle tension that often accompanies anxiety disorders. Many people hold tension in their shoulders, jaw, or stomach without realizing it. By systematically working through each muscle group, you develop greater body awareness and learn to release tension before it builds up.

tension.title: 5-Second Tension
tension.description: Deliberately contracting muscles activates awareness and prepares for deep release.

release.title: 15-Second Release
release.description: Extended relaxation allows muscles to reach deeper rest than normal baseline.

whenToPractice.title: When to practice
items: Before bedtime for better sleep quality
When feeling physically tense or tight
After stressful days to release accumulated tension
As part of daily relaxation routine

whatYoullNotice.title: What you'll notice
items: Physical tension melts away muscle by muscle
Mental chatter quiets as body deeply relaxes
Body feels heavy, warm, and completely at ease
Deep relaxation that improves sleep quality

environment.title: Environment
environment.description: Find a quiet, comfortable place where you won't be interrupted. Comfortable temperature helps focus.

tension.title: Tension Level
tension.description: Tense muscles firmly but avoid pain. Focus on the contrast between tension and relaxation.

consistency.title: Consistency
consistency.description: Regular practice improves your ability to recognize and release muscle tension quickly.

science.title: The Science Behind Progressive Muscle Relaxation
science.description: Meta-analyses indicate this technique reduces anxiety with a pooled effect size of 0.51 across 15 trials in adults. In COVID-19 patients, four weeks of practice improved sleep quality and lowered anxiety by 25%.

anxiety.title: Anxiety & Depression Relief
anxiety.description: Adolescents experienced a 20% drop in depression and stress levels after regular sessions. Combined with other methods, it achieves a 30% greater reduction in symptoms than standalone interventions.

medical.title: Medical Applications
medical.description: Cancer patients saw enhanced outcomes, with one review noting a 0.62 effect on fatigue and emotional distress. In COVID-19 patients, four weeks of practice improved sleep quality and lowered anxiety by 25%.

longterm.title: Long-term Effectiveness
longterm.description: Systematic reviews confirm its role in lowering trait anxiety, with effects comparable to biofeedback in long-term use. Meta-analyses indicate consistent anxiety reduction with a pooled effect size of 0.51 across 15 trials in adults.

rightHand.name: Right Hand & Forearm
tensionCue: Feel the tension in your fingers and forearm
relaxationCue: Feel fingers naturally curved and relaxed

leftHand.name: Left Hand & Forearm
tensionCue: Feel the tension in your fingers and forearm

rightUpperArm.name: Right Upper Arm
relaxationCue: Lower your arm to your side

leftUpperArm.name: Left Upper Arm
relaxationCue: Lower your arm to your side

forehead.name: Forehead & Scalp

eyesNose.name: Eyes & Nose

relaxationCue: Nose and cheeks smooth and relaxed

shoulders.name: Shoulders

abdomen.name: Abdomen

lowerBack.name: Lower Back

leftCalfShin.name: Left Calf & Shin

completion.title: Visualization Complete
completion.description: You've successfully journeyed to peaceful places within your mind. This calm state is always accessible to you.

mountainPeakSunrise.name: Mountain Peak Sunrise
mountainPeakSunrise.description: Standing atop a gentle mountain, watching the sun rise over endless peaks
guidance: You find yourself standing on a peaceful mountain peak, the world spread out before you like a beautiful painting.
The sunrise paints the sky in gentle colors - soft pinks, warm oranges, and golden yellows stretching across the horizon.
Cool, fresh mountain air fills your lungs. Each breath is pure and energizing, washing away any tension or worry.
Below you, layers of mountains roll into the distance like sleeping giants, covered in a soft morning mist.
You feel completely safe here, standing on solid ground, connected to the earth beneath your feet.
The sun's gentle warmth touches your face, filling you with peace and quiet strength.
This is your peaceful place - you can return here anytime by simply closing your eyes and remembering this moment.

tranquilForestGrove.name: Tranquil Forest Grove
tranquilForestGrove.description: In a sun-dappled clearing surrounded by ancient, gentle trees
guidance: You're walking into a beautiful forest clearing, where ancient trees create a natural cathedral around you.
Gentle sunlight filters through the leaves above, creating patterns of light and shadow on the forest floor.
The air here is filled with the fresh scent of growing things - moss, earth, and the clean smell of leaves.
Soft moss cushions your steps, and you can hear the peaceful sounds of birds singing and leaves rustling in the gentle breeze.
You settle beside a smooth tree trunk, feeling completely supported and safe in nature's embrace.
Every breath brings you deeper peace, as if the forest itself is sharing its ancient calm with you.
This grove is your sanctuary - a place where you can always find peace and renewal whenever you need it.

peacefulOceanBeach.name: Peaceful Ocean Beach
peacefulOceanBeach.description: Walking barefoot on warm sand beside gentle, rhythmic waves
guidance: You're walking barefoot on a beautiful beach, feeling the warm, soft sand between your toes.
Gentle waves roll onto the shore in a peaceful rhythm, like the earth's own breathing, calm and steady.
The ocean stretches endlessly before you, its surface sparkling in the sunlight like scattered diamonds.
A warm, gentle breeze carries the clean scent of salt water and touches your skin with perfect comfort.
You find the perfect spot to rest, feeling completely at peace with the endless rhythm of the waves.
Each wave that rolls in takes away any stress or worry, carrying it out to sea where it dissolves completely.
This beach is your peaceful refuge - the waves will always be here, ready to wash away your cares whenever you return.

sereneGardenParadise.name: Serene Garden Paradise
sereneGardenParadise.description: In a beautiful garden filled with colorful flowers and gentle fountains
guidance: You enter a magnificent garden where every flower seems to welcome you with vibrant colors and gentle fragrances.
A small fountain creates the most peaceful sound as clear water flows over smooth stones in the center of the garden.
Soft petals create a living rainbow around you - deep purples, bright yellows, soft pinks.
The air is filled with natural perfumes, and everything feels warm and welcoming.
You find a comfortable place to rest among the flowers, feeling safe and loved by nature.
This garden grows more beautiful with each breath you take, as if responding to your peaceful presence.
This is your garden of peace - it will always be in bloom, waiting for you whenever you need beauty and calm.

starlitMeadowNight.name: Starlit Meadow Night
starlitMeadowNight.description: Lying in a soft meadow under a blanket of countless stars
guidance: You're lying comfortably in a soft meadow, looking up at a sky filled with sparkling stars.
The grass beneath you is perfectly soft, like nature's own cushion, supporting your body completely.
Above you, the Milky Way stretches across the heavens like a river of light, beautiful beyond description.
The night air is comfortable, with a gentle breeze that carries the sweet scent of night-blooming flowers.
You feel small in the best possible way - connected to something vast and peaceful that holds you safely.
Each star seems to shine just for you, sending down light that fills you with wonder and peace.
This meadow under the stars is your place of infinite calm - you can always look up and find peace in the vastness.

howItWorks.title: How guided visualization works
howItWorks.description: Guided visualization leverages your brain's natural ability to create vivid mental experiences that feel real to your nervous system. When you imagine peaceful scenes in detail, your brain activates the same neural pathways as if you were actually experiencing those environments, triggering the relaxation response and reducing stress hormones.
howItWorks.multisensory: The multisensory nature of visualization - imagining sights, sounds, smells, and physical sensations - creates a comprehensive calming experience. Regular practice builds neural pathways that make relaxation more accessible, giving you a portable tool for managing anxiety and stress.

whenToPractice.title: When to practice
items: Start your morning with peaceful visualization to set a calm tone
Before stressful events to build confidence and inner peace
During lunch breaks for mental reset and stress relief
Before bedtime to unwind and prepare for restful sleep

whatYoullNotice.title: What you'll notice
items: Mind becomes calm and focused on peaceful imagery
Heart rate slows as stress melts away
Breathing becomes deeper and more natural
Whole body relaxes as you mentally "visit" peaceful places

preparation.title: Preparation
preparation.description: Find a comfortable position where you won't be disturbed. Close your eyes or soften your gaze.

engagement.title: Engagement
engagement.description: Engage all five senses - see, hear, feel, smell, taste. The more vivid, the more effective.

patience.title: Patience
patience.description: Don't worry if your mind wanders - gently return to the scene. Allow yourself to be creative.

science.title: The Science Behind Peaceful Visualization
science.description: Guided imagery lowers perioperative anxiety by 18% in surgical patients, as per a systematic review of 10 studies. Nature-based versions decrease state anxiety by activating relaxation responses, with a 15% reduction in cortisol.

effectiveness.title: Clinical Effectiveness
effectiveness.description: In group comparisons, visualization matched deep breathing's 20% relaxation boost. Virtual reality personalization cut anxiety by 22% in pilots, linking to prefrontal cortex changes.

medical.title: Medical Applications
medical.description: For infertile women, sessions reduced affective stress by 25% over controls. Cancer survivors reported a 20% quality-of-life gain in contemplative programs including visualization.

physiological.title: Physiological Benefits
physiological.description: Nature-based versions decrease state anxiety by activating relaxation responses, with a 15% reduction in cortisol. Guided imagery lowers perioperative anxiety by 18% in surgical patients across 10 studies.

interface.title: Thought Labeling
interface.subtitle: Observe and categorize your thoughts
interface.chooseLabelsThatDescribe: Choose the labels that best describe this thought:
interface.writeAnxiousThought: Write down an anxious thought you're having right now:
interface.examplePlaceholder: Example: 'I'm worried I'll mess up my presentation tomorrow...'

awareness.title: Awareness
awareness.description: Notice thoughts without being consumed by them

balance.title: Balance
balance.description: Create healthy distance from anxious thinking

completion.title: Excellent Self-Awareness
completion.description: You've successfully labeled {count} thought{plural} in {time}. This practice helps create healthy distance from anxious thinking.

commonPattern.title: Common Pattern Identified
commonPattern.description: Most of your thoughts were labeled as "{labelName}" - recognizing this pattern is the first step to managing it.

strongAwareness.title: Strong Self-Awareness
strongAwareness.description: You've shown excellent ability to observe and categorize your thoughts objectively.

worry.name: Worry
worry.description: Concerns about future events or outcomes

rejection.name: Rejection
rejection.description: Fear of being rejected or abandoned

health.name: Health
health.description: Concerns about physical or mental health

social.name: Social
social.description: Worries about social situations or relationships

cognitive.title: Cognitive Awareness
cognitive.description: When we're anxious, thoughts can feel overwhelming and all-consuming. Labeling creates psychological distance by helping you observe thoughts as mental events rather than absolute truths.
cognitive.therapy: This technique is rooted in cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and mindfulness practices, helping you develop metacognitive awarenessâ€”the ability to think about your thinking.

pattern.title: Pattern Recognition
pattern.description: By categorizing your thoughts, you begin to notice patterns in your thinking. Do you often engage in catastrophic thinking? Self-doubt? Perfectionism?
pattern.benefits: Recognizing these patterns is the first step toward developing healthier thought habits and reducing the emotional impact of anxious thinking.

science.title: The Science Behind Thought Labeling
science.description: Affect labeling diminishes amygdala activity, reducing emotional reactivity by 30% in response to negative stimuli. In mindfulness contexts, it correlates with anterior cingulate activation and a 15% anxiety relief.

cognitive.title: Cognitive Benefits
cognitive.description: Cognitive distortions in anxiety disorders, when labeled, show a 20% symptom drop in therapy trials. Exposure therapies incorporating labeling enhance inhibitory learning, improving outcomes by 25%.

neurological.title: Brain Changes
neurological.description: Mindfulness programs with labeling induce brain changes, cutting anxiety with a 0.40 effect size. In mindfulness contexts, it correlates with anterior cingulate activation and a 15% anxiety relief.

clinical.title: Clinical Applications
clinical.description: Post-TBI patients gained 18% in emotion regulation after training in labeling skills. Exposure therapies incorporating labeling enhance inhibitory learning, improving outcomes by 25%.

whenToPractice.title: When to practice
items: When your mind is spinning with racing thoughts
During catastrophic thinking or worst-case scenarios
When stuck ruminating on past events
During moments of self-doubt or questioning your worth

whatYoullNotice.title: What you'll notice
items: Greater distance from overwhelming thoughts
Recognition of recurring thought patterns
Reduced emotional reactivity to anxious thoughts
Improved metacognitive awareness over time

nonJudgmental.title: Stay Non-Judgmental
nonJudgmental.description: Label thoughts without criticism. There are no "bad" thoughtsâ€”only thoughts that may not be serving you well.

observe.title: Observe, Don't Engage
observe.description: The goal is to notice and categorize thoughts, not to solve or analyze them deeply in the moment.

practice.title: Practice Regularly
practice.description: Like any skill, thought labeling becomes more effective with practice. Use it daily for best results.

science.title: The Science Behind Tactile Stress Relief
science.description: Tactile fidget tools like stress balls lower anxiety by 15% in hemodialysis patients after four weeks. Sensory modulation interventions, including popping actions, reduce distress levels by 20% in mental health settings, helping improve self-regulation under stress.

sensory.title: Sensory Modulation
sensory.description: Sensory modulation interventions, including popping actions, reduce distress levels by 20% in mental health settings. Fidget devices improve self-regulation under stress, as shown by stabilized heart rates in lab tasks.

attention.title: Attention & Focus
attention.description: Among ADHD adults, fidgeting aids sustained attention, with a 12% performance boost. Parents of autistic children rate such tools as 25% more helpful for focus than in neurotypical groups.

motor.title: Motor Control Benefits
motor.description: Preliminary data suggest popping fidgets enhance fine motor control short-term by 10%. Tactile fidget tools like stress balls lower anxiety by 15% in hemodialysis patients after four weeks.

howItWorks.title: How Tactile Stress Relief Works
howItWorks.description: Tactile stimulation through repetitive popping motions provides immediate sensory feedback that helps redirect anxious energy. The satisfying 'pop' sound and physical sensation engage your nervous system in a calming, focused activity.

whenToPractice.title: When to use
items: During anxious moments when you need immediate distraction
When feeling restless or fidgety
During phone calls or waiting periods
As a quick stress reset between tasks

whatYoullNotice.title: What you'll notice
items: Immediate satisfying tactile feedback
Reduced restless energy and fidgeting
Improved focus during repetitive tasks
Quick stress relief through mindful popping

mindful.title: Mindful Popping
mindful.description: Focus on the sensation and sound of each pop rather than rushing through.

breaks.title: Take Breaks
breaks.description: Use for short 2-5 minute sessions to avoid overstimulation.

environment.title: Consider Others
environment.description: Be mindful of sound levels in quiet environments or shared spaces.

soundTherapy.title: Sound Therapy & Frequency Healing
soundTherapy.description: Experience therapeutic frequencies and binaural beats to promote deep relaxation, reduce anxiety, and enhance focus through scientifically-backed sound therapy.

playingState.description: Allow the healing vibrations to wash over you. Focus on your breath and let the frequencies guide you into deep relaxation.
playingState.instructions: Close your eyes and allow the vibrations to penetrate deeply, bringing peace to your mind and body.

science.title: The Science Behind Sound Therapy
science.description: Binaural beats at theta frequencies reduce preoperative anxiety by 20% in randomized trials. A pilot on college students found different beat frequencies cut autonomic stress markers by 15-25%.

clinical.title: Clinical Applications
clinical.description: In bronchoscopy patients, audio exposure lowered anxiety scores by 18 points. Meta-reviews show beats decrease pain perception and anxiety with a 0.35 effect size.

frequency.title: Frequency Effects
frequency.description: Daily use in diaries tracked a 10% anxiety drop over weeks. A pilot on college students found different beat frequencies cut autonomic stress markers by 15-25%.

combined.title: Combined Benefits
combined.description: Combined with music, it matches standalone therapy in symptom relief, improving by 12%. Meta-reviews show beats decrease pain perception and anxiety with a 0.35 effect size.

howItWorks.title: How Sound Therapy Works
howItWorks.description: Sound therapy uses specific frequencies and binaural beats to synchronize brainwaves and promote relaxation. Different frequencies target different states of consciousness, from deep meditation to alert focus.

frequencies.title: Therapeutic Frequencies
frequencies.description: Solfeggio frequencies have been used for centuries in meditation and healing practices. Each frequency is believed to resonate with different aspects of physical and emotional well-being.

binaural.title: Binaural Beats
binaural.description: When two slightly different frequencies are played in each ear, your brain creates a third frequency - the binaural beat. This can guide your brainwaves into specific states like relaxation or focus.

whenToPractice.title: When to use
items: During meditation or deep relaxation sessions
When you need to reduce anxiety before medical procedures
For pain management and stress relief
To improve focus and concentration
Before sleep for better rest quality

whatYoullNotice.title: What you'll notice
items: Gradual synchronization of breathing with sound waves
Deeper states of relaxation and calm
Reduced physical tension and mental chatter
Enhanced focus or meditative states
Improved pain tolerance and stress resilience

headphones.title: Use Headphones
headphones.description: Stereo headphones are essential for experiencing binaural beats effectively.

volume.title: Comfortable Volume
volume.description: Keep volume at a comfortable level - the therapy works through frequency, not loudness.

consistency.title: Regular Practice
consistency.description: Daily sessions of 10-20 minutes provide the most benefit for anxiety reduction.
